newsitem.title: GERMANY: Germany's SAP reports sharp Q1 profit rise.
newsitem.headline: Germany's SAP reports sharp Q1 profit rise.

text.p: German business software group SAP AG on Tuesday reported sharp increases in sales and earnings which it said were driven by the strength of the dollar and a number of new contracts.

The company said in a regulatory statement that sales in the first quarter surged 49 percent to 1.032 billion marks and pre-tax profits jumped 54 percent to 181 million marks. But the company said it would stick to its earlier forecast that sales would rise in the full year by some 25-30 percent.
The company said the strong first quarter sales were due to contracts it received from customers in the U.S., South Africa, India and France.
Currency markets, which have seen the dollar climb to 37 month highs against mark, also gave sales a boost.
Dietmar Hopp, SAP management board chairman, said he expected sales growth to slow somewhat from the first quarter's pace.
"Due to the high comparison figures from last year, especially in the fourth quarter, we expect for the year as a whole a flattening of sales growth," Hopp said.
